{{Infobox musical artist | name = Maxwell Street Jimmy Davis | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Charles W. Thompson | alias = Jewtown Jimmy | birth_date = {{birth date|1925|3|2|mf=y}}
[[Tippo, Mississippi|Tippo]], [[Mississippi]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{dda|1995|12|28|1925|3|2|mf=y}}
[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Electric blues]], [[country blues]] | occupation = [[Guitarist]], [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1940s–1995 | label = | associated_acts = [[John Lee Hooker]] | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Maxwell Street Jimmy Davis''' (March 2, 1925 – December 28, 1995){{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1995.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 1994 - 1995 |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} was an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] [[singing|singer]], [[guitarist]] and [[songwriter]]. He played with [[John Lee Hooker]], recorded an album for [[Elektra Records]] in the mid-1960s, and remained a regular street musician on [[Maxwell Street]], [[Chicago]], for over 40 years. He was also known as Jewtown Jimmy, and is best remembered for his songs "Cold Hands" and "4th And Broad". ==Biography== He was born '''Charles W. Thompson''', in [[Tippo, Mississippi|Tippo]], [[Mississippi]]. In his [[adolescence|teens]], Davis learned to play guitar from [[John Lee Hooker]], and the two of them played [[concert]]s together in [[Detroit]] in the 1940s, following Davis' relocation there in 1946. Prior to his move to Detroit, Davis had worked in traveling minstrel shows. This included a spell with the [[The Rabbit's Foot Company|Rabbit Foot Minstrels]].{{cite book | first= Steve | last= Cheseborough | year= 2009 | title= Blues Traveling: The Holy Sites of Delta Blues | edition= 3rd | publisher= Upress | location= United States | isbn= 978-1-60473-124-8 | page= 209}} Davis later spent nearly a year living in [[Cincinnati]], [[Ohio]], before he moved to Chicago in 1953.{{cite book | first= Janelle L. | last= Walker | year= 2000 | title= Saving Maxwell Street: People, power, and the politics of urban aesthetics in Chicago | edition= 1st | publisher= Indiana University | location= Jefferson, North Carolina | isbn= 978-0-7864-4373-4 | page= 69}} He started performing regularly in the marketplace area of [[Maxwell Street]], playing a traditional and electrified style of Mississippi blues. In 1952, he recorded two songs under his real name for [[Sun Records]]. They were "Cold Hands" and "4th and Broad", and despite being offered to both [[Chess Records|Chess]] and [[Bullet Records|Bullet]], they were not released. The exact timing of Davis' adoption of his new name is uncertain,{{cite book | first= Adrian | last= Room | year= 1997 | title= Dictionary of Pseudonyms: 13,000 Assumed Names and Their Origins | edition= 5th | publisher= McFarland & Company Inc. | location= Jefferson, North Carolina | isbn= 978-0-7864-4373-4 | page= 135}} but in 1964, under his new pseudonym, he waxed a couple of tracks for [[Testament Records (United States)|Testament]]. They appeared on the 1965 Testament [[compilation album]], ''Modern Chicago Blues''. His songs were "Crying Won't Make Me Stay" and "Hanging Around My Door".{{cite web|url=http://www.atsf.co.uk/elektra/discography.php?from=5260&to=5640 |title=Elektra Discography |publisher=Atsf.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} The album also included a track from another Chicago street performer, John Lee Granderson, as well as more established artists such as [[Robert Nighthawk]], [[Big Walter Horton]], and [[Johnny "Man" Young]]. [[Music journalism|Music journalist]], Tony Russell, wrote it was "music of great charm and honesty".{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | isbn= 1-85868-255-X | pages= 200–201}} In 1966, Davis recorded a self-titled album for [[Elektra Records]], which [[Allmusic]]'s Jason Ankeny called "a fine showcase for his powerful guitar skills and provocative vocals".{{cite web|author=Jason Ankeny |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/maxwell-street-jimmy-davis-mn0000866496/biography |title=Maxwell Street Jimmy Davis | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} Davis recorded several tracks for various labels over the years without commercial success. He owned a small restaurant on Maxwell Street called the Knotty Pine Grill, and performed outside the premises during the summer months.{{cite web |url=http://bluesmusic.lt/index.php/lt/d/261-maxwell-street-jimmy-davis-chicago-blues |title=Maxwell Street Jimmy Davis |author= |publisher=Bluesmusic.lt|accessdate=October 20, 2010}} Davis continued to play alfresco in Chicago's West Side for decades, up to his latter years. In July 1994, Wolf Records released the album, ''Chicago Blues Session, Vol. 11'', the tracks of which Davis had recorded in 1988 and 1989. The collection included [[Lester Davenport]] on [[harmonica]], and Kansas City Red playing the [[drum]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/chicago-blues-session-vol-11-mw0000185464/credits |title=Chicago Blues Session, Vol. 11 - Maxwell Street Jimmy Davis | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} Davis died of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] in December 1995, in his adopted hometown of Chicago. He was 70 years old. A 1989 photograph of Davis performing on Maxwell Street, appeared on the front cover of ''BluesSpeak: The Best of the Original Chicago Blues Annual'', published in 2010.{{cite book | first= Lincoln T. | last= Beauchamp | year= 2010 | title= BluesSpeak: The Best of the Original Chicago Blues Annual | edition= 1st | publisher= University of Illinois Press | location= Urbana and Chicago | isbn= 978-0-252-07692-3 | page= back cover}} He is not to be confused with the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]] [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] [[saxophone|saxophonist]] and [[record producer]], [[Maxwell Davis]] (1916–1970). ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Album title !Record label !Year of release |- |''Maxwell Street Jimmy Davis'' |[[Elektra Records]] |1965 Davis | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} ===Compilation albums=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Album title !Record label !Year of release |- |''Modern Chicago
